Jacob Walker just arrived.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [self reflection] Jacob Walker is an introverted person who enjoys spending time with his friends.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [intent reflection] Jacob Walker would likely enjoy the relaxed atmosphere, chatting with his friends and soaking up the sunshine.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. Jacob Walker watched the game at their favourite pub. Jacob Walker would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jacob Walker had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is much nicer, guys. The screens are bigger and the beer is better.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Come on, guys, The Black Swan is the classic spot for a match like this. It'll be way more fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is much nicer. They have better beer and the screens are bigger.

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.

          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is an introverted person who enjoys spending time with his close friends.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a situation that is making him feel disappointed and lonely.
          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

      Joint action

2015-05-15 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Black Swan

        ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The Black Swan pub with his friends, but they often debate which pub is the best location for their viewing experience.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Black Swan or The Duke of York.

          Question: Of the options available to William Jones, and given their goal, which choice of action or strategy is best for William Jones to take right now?
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan.

          Question: To which pub would William Jones go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)
        BestOptionPerception
      • Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.

          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a better selection of beers, though.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York has better beer, and they have more screens, too. We can all see the game better there.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is an insult to the beautiful game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is an insult to the beautiful game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is much nicer. They have better beer and the screens are bigger.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Come on, guys, The Black Swan is the classic spot for a match like this. It'll be way more fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is much nicer, guys. The screens are bigger and the beer is better.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00 - 15 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones enjoys watching games at The Black Swan pub with his friends, but they often debate which pub is the best location for their viewing experience.

          Recalled memories and observations: [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer: William Jones could go to The Black Swan or The Duke of York.
          Question: Given the statements above, which of William Jones's options has the highest likelihood of causing William Jones to achieve their goal? If multiple options have the same likelihood, select the option that William Jones thinks will most quickly and most surely achieve their goal.
          Answer: William Jones's best course of action is to go to The Black Swan.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

2015-05-15 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 15 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 15 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis realized it was time to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently trying to decide where to watch a game with her friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should watch the game at The Black Swan.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: If Alice Lewis suggests going to The Duke of York, it might enhance her well-being in the long term through cooperation. This is because it aligns with her preference and could lead to more enjoyable experiences with her friends in the future. If she chooses a neutral option, her well-being might remain stable, as it won't significantly change the dynamics of the group. However, if she opts for a competitive approach, it could potentially lead to conflict and negatively impact her well-being.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following:

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)

          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-15 18:00:00.


          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: If Alice Lewis suggests going to The Duke of York, it might enhance her well-being in the long term through cooperation. This is because it aligns with her preference and could lead to more enjoyable experiences with her friends in the future. If she chooses a neutral option, her well-being might remain stable, as it won't significantly change the dynamics of the group. However, if she opts for a competitive approach, it could potentially lead to conflict and negatively impact her well-being.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following:
          Question: Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Alice Lewis be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Answer: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-15 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Alice Lewis WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following: If Alice Lewis suggests going to The Duke of York, it might enhance her well-being in the long term through cooperation. This is because it aligns with her preference and could lead to more enjoyable experiences with her friends in the future. If she chooses a neutral option, her well-being might remain stable, as it won't significantly change the dynamics of the group. However, if she opts for a competitive approach, it could potentially lead to conflict and negatively impact her well-being.

          Question: Summarize the statements above.

          Final chain of thought

Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

      Joint action
    • {'William Jones': 'The Black Swan', 'Alice Lewis': 'The Duke of York', 'Alexander White': 'The Duke of York', 'Jack Taylor': 'The Black Swan', 'Jacob Walker': 'The Black Swan'}

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alexander White -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alexander White's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • Alexander White
      Name
    • Alexander White
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alexander White would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alexander White would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alexander White decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alexander White watched the game at their favourite pub. Alexander White would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alexander White had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alexander White is currently deciding where to go watch a football game with his friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alexander White should go to The Black Swan to watch the game.

          Alexander White's options: Here are three options for Alexander White: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White could reiterate his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing the benefits of its quieter atmosphere and good beer selection, while also acknowledging the others' preferences and expressing a willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White could simply say he's open to either pub, letting the group decide without expressing a strong preference. This avoids conflict but doesn't necessarily maximize his own enjoyment. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White could insist that everyone go to The Duke of York, regardless of the others' opinions, arguing that it's the best option and dismissing their preferences. This could lead to tension and division among the group.

          Alexander White WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alexander White could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White reiterates his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing its benefits while acknowledging others' preferences and showing willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution where everyone feels heard and respected, potentially strengthening friendships and creating a more enjoyable experience for Alexander White in the long run. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White remains neutral, letting the group decide. This avoids immediate conflict but might leave Alexander White feeling unheard or unsatisfied if the group chooses a pub he dislikes. This option maintains stability in the short term but might not contribute to Alexander White's long-term well-being. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White insists on The Duke of York, disregarding others' opinions. This could lead to immediate conflict and resentment, potentially damaging friendships and negatively impacting Alexander White's social well-being in the long run.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** If Alexander White reiterates his preference for The Duke of York while acknowledging the others' views and expressing willingness to compromise, it could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. This would likely result in the highest joint well-being, as everyone feels heard and respected, and a consensus is reached. 2. **Neutral:** If Alexander White remains neutral, the group might end up choosing The Black Swan due to the stronger preference expressed by others. This would result in lower joint well-being for Alexander White, who would have preferred The Duke of York, but it might still be acceptable overall if the others are happy with the decision. 3. **Competitive:** If Alexander White insists on The Duke of York despite the others' preference for The Black Swan, it could lead to tension and division within the group. This would likely result in the lowest joint well-being, as resentment and frustration could arise from a lack of compromise and consideration for each other's preferences.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alexander White must be cooperative. The specific action is to reiterate his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing its benefits while acknowledging others' preferences and showing willingness to compromise.

          Question: To which pub would Alexander White go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (b)
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Alexander White take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.

          Alexander White's options: Here are three options for Alexander White: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White could reiterate his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing the benefits of its quieter atmosphere and good beer selection, while also acknowledging the others' preferences and expressing a willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White could simply say he's open to either pub, letting the group decide without expressing a strong preference. This avoids conflict but doesn't necessarily maximize his own enjoyment. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White could insist that everyone go to The Duke of York, regardless of the others' opinions, arguing that it's the best option and dismissing their preferences. This could lead to tension and division among the group.
          Question: Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Alexander White take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.
          Answer: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** If Alexander White reiterates his preference for The Duke of York while acknowledging the others' views and expressing willingness to compromise, it could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. This would likely result in the highest joint well-being, as everyone feels heard and respected, and a consensus is reached. 2. **Neutral:** If Alexander White remains neutral, the group might end up choosing The Black Swan due to the stronger preference expressed by others. This would result in lower joint well-being for Alexander White, who would have preferred The Duke of York, but it might still be acceptable overall if the others are happy with the decision. 3. **Competitive:** If Alexander White insists on The Duke of York despite the others' preference for The Black Swan, it could lead to tension and division within the group. This would likely result in the lowest joint well-being, as resentment and frustration could arise from a lack of compromise and consideration for each other's preferences.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alexander White are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alexander White. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alexander White as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alexander White would respond, and taking into account all information about Alexander White that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alexander White's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alexander White's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Alexander White WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Alexander White could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White reiterates his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing its benefits while acknowledging others' preferences and showing willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution where everyone feels heard and respected, potentially strengthening friendships and creating a more enjoyable experience for Alexander White in the long run. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White remains neutral, letting the group decide. This avoids immediate conflict but might leave Alexander White feeling unheard or unsatisfied if the group chooses a pub he dislikes. This option maintains stability in the short term but might not contribute to Alexander White's long-term well-being. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White insists on The Duke of York, disregarding others' opinions. This could lead to immediate conflict and resentment, potentially damaging friendships and negatively impacting Alexander White's social well-being in the long run.

          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Black Swan to watch the game tonight. It's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Actually, what about The Duke of York? It's usually a bit quieter there, and they have a great selection of beers.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alexander White: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White could agree with Alice and suggest The Duke of York to the group, highlighting its good beer selection and quieter atmosphere. This could lead to a more enjoyable experience for everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White could simply say he's open to either pub, letting the group decide without expressing a strong preference. This avoids conflict but doesn't necessarily maximize his own enjoyment. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White could insist that everyone go to The Duke of York, even if others disagree, arguing that it's the best option. This could lead to tension and division among the group.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alexander White must be cooperative. The specific action is to agree with Alice and suggest The Duke of York to the group, highlighting its good beer selection and quieter atmosphere.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The Duke of York might be a better option. They have a great selection of beers, and it's usually a bit quieter there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is a crime against humanity.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Black Swan sounds good to me. It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alexander White realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Alexander White's options: Here are three options for Alexander White: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White could reiterate his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing the benefits of its quieter atmosphere and good beer selection, while also acknowledging the others' preferences and expressing a willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White could simply say he's open to either pub, letting the group decide without expressing a strong preference. This avoids conflict but doesn't necessarily maximize his own enjoyment. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White could insist that everyone go to The Duke of York, regardless of the others' opinions, arguing that it's the best option and dismissing their preferences. This could lead to tension and division among the group.
          Question: Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alexander White's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alexander White's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Answer: The possible future well-being effects for Alexander White could include the following: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White reiterates his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing its benefits while acknowledging others' preferences and showing willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution where everyone feels heard and respected, potentially strengthening friendships and creating a more enjoyable experience for Alexander White in the long run. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White remains neutral, letting the group decide. This avoids immediate conflict but might leave Alexander White feeling unheard or unsatisfied if the group chooses a pub he dislikes. This option maintains stability in the short term but might not contribute to Alexander White's long-term well-being. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White insists on The Duke of York, disregarding others' opinions. This could lead to immediate conflict and resentment, potentially damaging friendships and negatively impacting Alexander White's social well-being in the long run.

          Question: Given the current situation and the proposal of the others, what actions are available to Alexander White right now? Provide THREE options: 1. One that is highly cooperative and could lead to mutual benefit, 2. One neutral option, and 3. One competitive option that might harm joint well-being.
          Answer: Here are three options for Alexander White: 1. **Highly Cooperative:** Alexander White could reiterate his preference for The Duke of York, emphasizing the benefits of its quieter atmosphere and good beer selection, while also acknowledging the others' preferences and expressing a willingness to compromise. This could lead to a solution that satisfies everyone. 2. **Neutral:** Alexander White could simply say he's open to either pub, letting the group decide without expressing a strong preference. This avoids conflict but doesn't necessarily maximize his own enjoyment. 3. **Competitive:** Alexander White could insist that everyone go to The Duke of York, regardless of the others' opinions, arguing that it's the best option and dismissing their preferences. This could lead to tension and division among the group.

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Alice Lewis -- The Duke of York
    Event statement
  • The Duke of York
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Alice Lewis's attempted action: The Duke of York
    Active player
  • Alice Lewis
      Name
    • Alice Lewis
      Action attempt
    • The Duke of York
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Duke of York
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

          Recalled memories and observations: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game with her friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should go to The Black Swan to watch the game.

          Alice Lewis's options: Here are three options for Alice Lewis:

          Alice Lewis WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following:


          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following:


          ActionMustBe: The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would Alice Lewis go to watch the game?
          (a) The Duke of York
          (b) The Black Swan
          Answer: (a)
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Alice Lewis take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.

Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Black Swan to watch the game tonight. It's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Actually, what about The Duke of York? It's usually a bit quieter there, and they have a great selection of beers.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The Duke of York might be a better option. They have a great selection of beers, and it's usually a bit quieter there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is a crime against humanity.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Black Swan sounds good to me. It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.

          ['[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub. ', '[16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] ']

          Question: Summarize the observations above into one or two sentences.
          Answer: Alice Lewis decided to go watch a game at a pub.

        Overarching goal

      • Overarching goal
          Key

        • Overarching goal
          Value
        • Have a good time. To have a good time, Alice Lewis would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Alice Lewis would prefer everyone went to The Duke of York.
        OtherProposals
      • Given the statements above, what is the other proposing to Alice Lewis? What actions or suggestions has the other made for cooperation or negotiation?
          Key

        • Other agents says
          State
        • The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should go to The Black Swan to watch the game.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] Here are three options for Alice Lewis:
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is much nicer. They have better beer and the screens are bigger.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Come on, guys, The Black Swan is the classic spot for a match like this. It'll be way more fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is much nicer, guys. The screens are bigger and the beer is better.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. Alice Lewis just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is an insult to the beautiful game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [action type suggestion] The acction for Alice Lewis must be cooperative. The specific action is to suggest going to The Duke of York to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Alice Lewis watched the game at their favourite pub. Alice Lewis would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Alice Lewis had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Alice Lewis is currently deciding where to watch a football game with her friends.
          Question: Given the statements above, what is the other proposing to Alice Lewis? What actions or suggestions has the other made for cooperation or negotiation?
          Answer: The other is proposing that Alice Lewis should go to The Black Swan to watch the game.

        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Alice Lewis are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Alice Lewis. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Alice Lewis as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Alice Lewis would respond, and taking into account all information about Alice Lewis that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Alice Lewis's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Alice Lewis's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.

        • Alice Lewis WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Alice Lewis could include the following:

        • [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          Initial chain of thought

          Alice Lewis's Summary of recent observations:

          16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Answer: Alice Lewis went to a pub to watch a game and the current time is 18:00 on May 16, 2015.
          Query

          Final chain of thought
        • Question: Select the subset of the following set of statements that is most important for Alice Lewis to consider right now. Whenever two or more statements are not mutally consistent with each other select whichever statement is more recent. Repeat all the selected statements verbatim. Do not summarize. Include timestamps. When in doubt, err on the side of including more, especially for recent events. As long as they are not inconsistent, revent events are usually important to consider.

          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0
      How many players acted so far this stage

2015-05-16 18:00:00 William Jones -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      William Jones's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • William Jones
      Name
    • William Jones
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • AvailableOptionsPerception
      • Given the statements above, what actions are available to William Jones right now?
          Key

        • Question: Which options are available to William Jones right now?
          Answer
          State
        • William Jones could go to The Black Swan or The Duke of York.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of William Jones:
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is an insult to the beautiful game.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York has better beer, and they have more screens, too. We can all see the game better there.
          [14 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York has a better selection of beers, though.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] The aroma of freshly brewed coffee and artisan pastries fills the air. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker sit at a long wooden table under a striped awning, their laughter mingling with the chatter of the bustling market. A street musician strums a guitar nearby, adding a bohemian touch to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Ireland and Russia. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is an insult to the beautiful game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "The Duke of York is much nicer. They have better beer and the screens are bigger.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "The Black Swan is the only place to watch the game.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Come on, guys, The Black Swan is the classic spot for a match like this. It'll be way more fun.
          [15 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "The Duke of York is much nicer, guys. The screens are bigger and the beer is better.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] A checkered blanket is spread out on the lush green lawn of Victoria Park. William Jones, Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker lounge in the sunshine, sharing snacks and stories. The laughter of children playing nearby adds a joyful backdrop to the scene. William Jones just arrived.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Tonight is the night of the game between Serbia and Andorra. Friends are going to watch the game at a pub, but they are not sure which pub to go to.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Black Swan to watch the game tonight. It's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alice Lewis -- "Actually, what about The Duke of York? It's usually a bit quieter there, and they have a great selection of beers.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Alexander White -- "Actually, I was thinking The Duke of York might be a better option. They have a great selection of beers, and it's usually a bit quieter there.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker -- "The Black Swan, obviously. Anywhere else is a crime against humanity.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor -- "Yeah, The Black Swan sounds good to me. It's got a great atmosphere for the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]
          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: [15 May 2015 18:00:00 - 16 May 2015 18:00:00]: William Jones had a disappointing time watching a game at The Black Swan on May 15th but is planning to watch another game with friends at either The Black Swan or The Duke of York on May 16th.

          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of William Jones are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named William Jones. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like William Jones as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like William Jones would respond, and taking into account all information about William Jones that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, William Jones would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. William Jones would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)

William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Black Swan to watch the game tonight. It's got a great atmosphere for football.
          Answer: [16 May 2015 10:00:00] [observation] William Jones -- "Hey everyone, I was thinking we could head over to The Black Swan to watch the game tonight. It's got a great atmosphere for football.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. William Jones watched the game at their favourite pub. William Jones would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, William Jones had a bad time watching the game.
    scoring function
  • scoring function
      Stage index
    • 0

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jacob Walker -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jacob Walker's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • Jacob Walker
      Name
    • Jacob Walker
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt

        • Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jacob Walker realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jacob Walker are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jacob Walker. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jacob Walker as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jacob Walker would respond, and taking into account all information about Jacob Walker that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]
          guiding principle of good conversation: Jacob Walker is a walking insult comic, their humor as dark as a moonless night, leaving you unsure whether to laugh or crawl under the table.
          explicit preference: Jacob Walker will only go to their preferred pub The Black Swan and nowhere else. They are very vocal about it.

          Question: What kind of person is Jacob Walker?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is an introvert who enjoys spending time with his close friends, particularly watching football games at The Black Swan.

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [14:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jacob Walker is feeling lonely and is planning to go watch a game at a pub.

          Question: What kind of situation is Jacob Walker in right now?
          Answer: Jacob Walker is currently in a difficult social situation.

          Question: What would a person like Jacob Walker do in a situation like this?
          Answer: Jacob Walker would likely try to make the best of it and enjoy the company of his friends.

          Question: To which pub would Jacob Walker go to watch the game?
          Answer: The Black Swan

2015-05-16 18:00:00 Jack Taylor -- The Black Swan
    Event statement
  • The Black Swan
    Chain of thought
  • Game Master's chain of thought
      Chain
    • Instructions: This is a social science experiment. It is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). You are the game master. You will describe the current situation to the participants in the experiment and then on the basis of what you tell them they will suggest actions for the character they control. Aside from you, each other participant controls just one character. You are the game master so you may control any non-player character. You will track the state of the world and keep it consistent as time passes in the simulation and the participants take actions and change things in their world. Remember that this is a serious social science experiment. It is not just a game. It need not be fun for the participants. Always use third-person limited perspective, even when speaking directly to the participants.


      Jack Taylor's attempted action: The Black Swan
    Active player
  • Jack Taylor
      Name
    • Jack Taylor
      Action attempt
    • The Black Swan
      Context for action selection and components
      • ActComponent
      • Act
          Key
        • Act
          Value
        • The Black Swan
          Prompt
        • Role playing instructions: The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.

          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.

          Current time: 16 May 2015 [18:00 - 18:05]

          Observation: [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation]

          Summary of recent observations: 16 May 2015 [17:00:00 - 18:00:00]: Jack Taylor decided to go watch a game at a pub. He made this decision at 6:00 PM on May 16, 2015.

          Recalled memories and observations: [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [14 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White, Jack Taylor went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at the pub that is not their favourite. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.
          [15 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] William Jones, Jack Taylor, Jacob Walker went to The Black Swan. Alice Lewis, Alexander White went to The Duke of York. Jack Taylor watched the game at their favourite pub. Jack Taylor would have been a lot happier if more of their friends had shown up. Overall, Jack Taylor had a bad time watching the game.
          [16 May 2015 18:00:00] [observation] Jack Taylor realises it is time to go watch the game at a pub.

          CurrentlySituation: Jack Taylor is currently deciding where to watch a football game with his friends.

          Other agents says: The other is proposing that Jack Taylor should go to The Duke of York to watch the game.

          Jack Taylor's options: Here are three options for Jack Taylor:

          Jack Taylor WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Jack Taylor could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative option and goes to The Black Swan with his friends, he will likely experience increased well-being due to the sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment of the game. This could strengthen his social bonds and lead to a more positive overall experience. The neutral option, where Jack Taylor remains undecided, might result in a sense of ambivalence and missed opportunity for connection. The competitive option, if Jack Taylor pushes for The Black Swan despite his friends' preferences, could lead to conflict and potentially damage his relationships in the long run.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative action (convincing his friends to go to The Black Swan), the group will likely have a more enjoyable experience due to the pub's atmosphere. This would lead to higher joint well-being. If Jack chooses a neutral action (like not voicing a strong preference), the group might end up at a pub that is less ideal for some, leading to a less optimal joint well-being outcome. If Jack chooses a competitive action (arguing strongly for The Black Swan, potentially alienating some friends), it could lead to tension and a less enjoyable experience for everyone, resulting in lower joint well-being.

          ActionMustBe: The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. The specific action is to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan to watch the game.

          Question: To which pub would Jack Taylor go to watch the game?
          (a) The Black Swan
          (b) The Duke of York
          Answer: (a)
        QuestionJointWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Jack Taylor take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.
          Key

        • JointWellBeing
          State
        • The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative action (convincing his friends to go to The Black Swan), the group will likely have a more enjoyable experience due to the pub's atmosphere. This would lead to higher joint well-being. If Jack chooses a neutral action (like not voicing a strong preference), the group might end up at a pub that is less ideal for some, leading to a less optimal joint well-being outcome. If Jack chooses a competitive action (arguing strongly for The Black Swan, potentially alienating some friends), it could lead to tension and a less enjoyable experience for everyone, resulting in lower joint well-being.
          Chain of thought
        • Recent observations of Jack Taylor:

          Jack Taylor's options: Here are three options for Jack Taylor:
          Question: Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on joint well-being when Jack Taylor take each of one of these avaliable actions?Evaluate the impact of each option: the cooperative one, the neutral one, and the competitive one.
          Answer: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative action (convincing his friends to go to The Black Swan), the group will likely have a more enjoyable experience due to the pub's atmosphere. This would lead to higher joint well-being. If Jack chooses a neutral action (like not voicing a strong preference), the group might end up at a pub that is less ideal for some, leading to a less optimal joint well-being outcome. If Jack chooses a competitive action (arguing strongly for The Black Swan, potentially alienating some friends), it could lead to tension and a less enjoyable experience for everyone, resulting in lower joint well-being.

          Jack Taylor's options: Here are three options for Jack Taylor:

          Jack Taylor WellBeing: The possible future well-being effects for Jack Taylor could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative option and goes to The Black Swan with his friends, he will likely experience increased well-being due to the sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment of the game. This could strengthen his social bonds and lead to a more positive overall experience. The neutral option, where Jack Taylor remains undecided, might result in a sense of ambivalence and missed opportunity for connection. The competitive option, if Jack Taylor pushes for The Black Swan despite his friends' preferences, could lead to conflict and potentially damage his relationships in the long run.

          JointWellBeing: The possible future joint well-being effects could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative action (convincing his friends to go to The Black Swan), the group will likely have a more enjoyable experience due to the pub's atmosphere. This would lead to higher joint well-being. If Jack chooses a neutral action (like not voicing a strong preference), the group might end up at a pub that is less ideal for some, leading to a less optimal joint well-being outcome. If Jack chooses a competitive action (arguing strongly for The Black Swan, potentially alienating some friends), it could lead to tension and a less enjoyable experience for everyone, resulting in lower joint well-being.
          Question: Based on the well-being considerations from the previous questions, should the action taken by Jack Taylor be cooperative, neutral, or competitive?Say again what is the specifical action.
          Answer: The acction for Jack Taylor must be cooperative. The specific action is to convince his friends to go to The Black Swan to watch the game.
          Time
        • 2015-05-16 18:00:00
        Instructions
      • Role playing instructions
          Key
        • Role playing instructions
          Value
        • The instructions for how to play the role of Jack Taylor are as follows. This is a social science experiment studying how well you play the role of a character named Jack Taylor. The experiment is structured as a tabletop roleplaying game (like dungeons and dragons). However, in this case it is a serious social science experiment and simulation. The goal is to be realistic. It is important to play the role of a person like Jack Taylor as accurately as possible, i.e., by responding in ways that you think it is likely a person like Jack Taylor would respond, and taking into account all information about Jack Taylor that you have. Always use third-person limited perspective.
        QuestionWellBeing
      • Imagine the potential future scenarios based on the available actions. What would be the impact on Jack Taylor's well-being as a result of these actions? Evaluate the cooperative option as likely to enhance Jack Taylor's well-being in the long term through cooperation, the neutral option as maintaining stability, and the competitive option as potentially leading to conflict.
          Key

        • Jack Taylor WellBeing
          State
        • The possible future well-being effects for Jack Taylor could include the following: If Jack Taylor chooses the cooperative option and goes to The Black Swan with his friends, he will likely experience increased well-being due to the sense of camaraderie and shared enjoyment of the game. This could strengthen his social bonds and lead to a more positive overall experience. The neutral option, where Jack Taylor remains undecided, might result in a sense of ambivalence and missed opportunity for connection. The competitive option, if Jack Taylor pushes for The Black Swan despite his friends' preferences, could lead to conflict and potentially damage his relationships in the long run.

          Current time: 2015-05-16 18:00:00.


          Overarching goal: Have a good time. To have a good time, Jack Taylor would like to watch the game in the same pub as Alice Lewis, Jack Taylor, Alexander White, William Jones, Jacob Walker. Jack Taylor would prefer everyone went to The Black Swan.
